parsetree.*:
<root><template><title>RV</title><part><name>type</name>=<value>command

</value></part><part><name index="1"/><value> ofp

</value></part><part><name index="2"/><value>1.00

</value></part><part><name>gr1</name>=<value> Math - Geometry

</value></part><part><name index="3"/><value> Cosine of a number, argument in degrees.

</value></part><part><name index="4"/><value> '''cos''' x

</value></part><part><name>p1</name>=<value>  x: [[Number]]

</value></part><part><name index="5"/><value> [[Number]]
		  
</value></part><part><name>x1</name>=<value> <code>[[cos]] 60;//returns 0.5</code>

</value></part><part><name>seealso</name>=<value> [[acos]], [[sin]], [[asin]], [[tan]], [[atan]], [[atan2]]
</value></part></template>

<dl class="command_description">
<comment><!-- Note Section BEGIN -->
</comment>
<dd class="notedate">Posted on August 8, 2006 - 23:54</dd>
<dt class="note">[[User:Hardrock|hardrock]]<dd class="note">Be aware that there might be rounding errors in the results of this command.

 cos 90

for example doesn't return the expected '0', but '-4.37114e-008'. So, if you want to compare results of Cosinus, don't use the compare operator

 (cos 90)<ext><name>nowiki</name><attr/><inner>==</inner><close></nowiki></close></ext>0

but rather use less than.

 (cos 90) < 0.00001


<comment><!-- Note Section END -->
</comment></dl>
